subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: ... Read already put quite a burden on non-rhotic speakers by demanding of them that they write Roe everywhere where rhotic speakers pronounce /r/. In that
messageBody:
John Cowan skrev:
> Benct Philip Jonsson scripsit:
>
>> Wells also makes a good case for not distinguishing the
>> lexical sets TRAP-FATHER-BATH (At-Ah in QS terminology)
>> or LOT-THOUGHT-CLOTH (QS Ox-Awe). For all Read's genius
>> when it came to Utter-and-Ado he seems to have been
>> overly home- blind and maximist concerning these lexical
>> sets. I find Awe and Ah cumbersome to write, and would
>> not shed a tear if they were abolished, or used only to
>> write foreign names.
>
> The trouble is, of course, the large and growing number of
> people for whom LOT = CLOTH = THOUGHT = PALM. Shall we go
> down from two letters to only one? That seems much too
> minimalist to me, but doing anything else continues to
> involve us in arbitrary distinctions.

Read already put quite a burden on non-rhotic speakers by
demanding of them that they write Roe everywhere where
rhotic speakers pronounce /r/. In that light it is perhaps
not unreasonable to expect that speakers who have merged all
of LOT-(CLOTH)-THOUGHT-FATHER to write their /A/ mostly with
Ox but sometimes with At, but relieve them of having to
learn *three* different 'orthographic sets' with Ox, Awe or
Ah for one single phoneme, by postulating that Ox be written
wherever non-merging speakers have /Q/ or /O/ and Ah
wherever non-merging speakers have /A/ or /{/.

It would perhaps take some getting used to for everyone to
write and read STARTas At-Roe and NORTH as Ox-Roe, but this
would be the logical consequence if Awe and Ah are to be
used only in foreign names and unassimilated words, similar
to Loch and Llan. Ah would then be used only in foreign
names and words where the foreign pronunciation has an /A/
or /a/ type vowel, and Awe similarly for a foreign /O/ or
/o/ type vowel -- the latter to be pronounced with the
THOUGHT vowel for those who have it distinct from LOT and
FATHER and with the GOAT vowel by others.

The Roe-rule and the At-Ox-rule would then in a way cancel
each other out in terms of requiring non-phonemic spellings
to be learnt by rote by non-rhotic and LOT-THOUGHT-FATHER-
merging speakers respectively. The functional load of the
LOT-THOUGHT and TRAP-FATHER distinctions isn't very big for
those who have it, and neither is the set of words where
LOT-THOUGHT-FATHER-merging speakers would need to remember
to spell their /A/ vowel with At.

Thus I further propose that where unstressed TO i and e
correspond to /@/ in some accents but /I/ in others It is
to be written, since in those accents which have /I/ in
these words it often corresponds minimally to /@/
corresponding to TO vowel + r, and a misreading may be
unfortunate. In Accents of English (I can go to the library
and look up the page if anybody wants me to) Wells cites
the story of the Australian-born news readers whose
_chatted_ sounded like _chattered_ to his Southern British
audience -- a cause of embarrassment since it was the Queen
who had done the chatting! This will further balance the
tax which the Roe-rule puts on non-rhotic speakers, since
the majority of rhotic speakers will have to learn this
It-Utter-
rule by rote.



> (While I'm at it, I should apologize for assuming that
> everybody elides /l/ in "palm" and similar words. Clearly
> not true, although in my four-person five-accent household
> only one of us fails to elide it.)

In the pronunciation key to LPD Wells in every case gives
his lexical set label words as the first keyword for the
vowels, but for RP /A/ == GenAm /A/ he gives _start,
father_, with no _palm_ in sight, so he too seems to have
come to see PALM as problematic as a label for this set.

>> That's exactly the problem with TO, which not only
>> persists in making distinctions that were lost before
>> Shakespeare, or already in Latin or Old French in the
>> case of loanwords,
>
> The real problem is the spellings that have become
> completely randomized with time, that are predictable by
> no rule however complicated (aka "maggelitous"). Fix all
> of those, and we would get a long way to rational Inglish,
> as Axel Wijk demonstrated.

IMHO that is two ways of saying the same thing. As you know
I tend to be historically-minded.

John Cowan skrev:
> Anthony Grahn scripsit:
>
>> - We've made several charts for several accents mapping
>> lexical sets to QS letters. Which one should a foreign
>> student of QS use: which English accent is the right
>> one to learn?
>
> Whichever is taught in his country and/or will be more
> useful for him to learn.

Unfortunately these two criteria don't always coincide. Most
accents of Swedish have only three back vowel phonemes /u o
A/ and no real diphthongs except vowel + /j/ combos and an
unstable /A8/ or /Au/ in some foreign borrowings, yet
schools and universities continue to teach RP when
clearly General American would be easier to learn for
most Swedes.

>
>> - We have spent massive effort accommodating accents
>> spoken by tiny groups of English-As-First-Language
>> speakers (there's a whole letter just for Welsh place
>> names) but none at all to accommodate ESL accents. This
>> even where a single accent is used by millions (eg
>> native Spanish speakers). Would it not, from a purely
>> rational standpoint, make as much sense to accommodate
>> at least a few of the near billion ESL speakers world
>> wide as to accommodate a few hundred thousand native
>> English speakers with a rare vowel merger?

My proposals (the Ox-At-rule and the It-Utter-rule)
essentially involve General American (the largest single
speaker group) against most of the rest, as does Read's
original Roe-rule. On page 20 of QM Read has a Terminal-y
rule which for most modern speakers amounts to a rule for
spelling unstressed /i/ in final syllables with It, but
stressed final-syllable /i/ with Eat. I propose to call this
rule the It-Eat-rule. For most native English speakers it
then comes down to four spelling rules which are non-
phonemic to some or all and will have to be learnt by rote.

> Mergers make for complications, but not extra
> letters, unless you are going to assign a novel
> letter to the merged sound, which I hope no one will
> want to do. Probably most ESL speakers have mergers
> rather than splits.

Actually many Scandinavians have a split in KIT depending on
where it is spelled with i or y. You will also have some
free variation between different front and central rounded
vowels for STRUT, which in as far as speakers are consistent
in their assignment of a particular sound to particular
words amounts to a split.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se

No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
if grammarians discuss them.
-Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
